ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: i'm truly not sure if i learned anything here. maybe a couple of things about solar power.

Knowledge of various types of energy sources, their benefits and problems, and insight into how they relate to each other and likely outcomes of use, especially with respect to economic and climate change issues.
The seminar discusses various forms of energies and the challenges surrounding their application and policy regulations

This class provided a great breadth of knowledge on contemporary issues in energy policy, from solar to wind. It was great for getting a basic understanding for the issues. That said, a little more economic theory would have been interesting.
I learned a lot about global energy sources, a good background on energy policy

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: this class was mind-numbingly boring. don't bother doing the reading because it is RIDICULOUSLY long and he doesn't even ask about it -- this is not a seminar, this is a lecture. staying awake for 2 hours at 9:25 was truly a challenge.
Strengths : very well taught, very relevant, incredibly synthesized and interrelated material. Cons: not much student engagement (although most students view that as a pro)
This class covers a wide range of topics, so it inevitably lacks depth in each topic
The course could be improved by instituting more detailed feedback mechanisms.
Overall I thought this class was great! One comment- I wish it was structured more like a seminar and had more in class discussions, rather than just lecture and Q&A

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: not my favorite course. it's a lecture posing as a seminar, but it is so mind-numbingly boring that i really don't think i could recommend that anyone sit through this. the readings are incredibly dense and long and just don't do them, it isn't worth it.
Incredible accomplished person in his field taking time to teach people. If you get over the fact that it is at 9am, you will end learning a lot from this professor.
Highly highly recommend this class! Professor kessides provides an extremely well balanced analysis that is a rarity at Yale
Yes I would absolutely recommend the course to any studen t interested in energy.
Yes, if you're interested in energy policy definitely take this class!

This is a great survey class if you want to know more about the topic of different types of energies, but ultimately it's just a lecture and there is little engagement in the course. If you are truly committed to the readings, you'll likely learn a lot, but otherwise Professor Kessides is pretty hands off. I didn't believe that in previous course evaluations, but it's very true. Don't expect too much instruction or feedback from this course.
yes, its great if you're in the energy studies program. I thought there was a lot of relevant info.
Kessides is an expert on all things energy. If you pay attention, you'll learn a lot. But, given that it is entirely lecture-based, it is hard to pay attention and not goof off.
